newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends up on Egypt talk, China hopes.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends up on Egypt talk, China hopes.

text.p: Talk that Egypt may be in the market late Friday or over the weekend for U.S. wheat boosted CBOT wheat futures to a higher close, traders said.
After the close it was confirmed Egypt was seeking 50,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat for September or October shipment.
Support also may have come from hopes for U.S. wheat business with China this year.

"Glickman says China might buy U.S. wheat and that may have helped wheat a bit," said Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds, referring to USDA Secretary Dan Glickman's remark that China may return to the U.S. wheat market this marketing year. But Glickman also cast a cautious pall on his remarks.
"I still think they'll be in the market, but it does seem to be a more competitive marketplace out there," Glickman told Reuters.
Refco Inc bought 1.5 million bushels of December and SAK Futures bought two million December, they said.
Gains in wheat were limited by a recent slowdown in U.S. wheat exports and diminished fears about weather threats to the U.S. and Canadian spring wheat crops.
Wheat closed two to four cents per bushel higher, with September up 2-1/4 at $4.52-3/4.
Wheat futures volume was estimated at 13,000, up from 9,648 Thursday, according to the CBOT.

In the wheat options pit the September expired without fanfare and the focus was on put demand in the December, they said. Lind Waldock bought 500 December $4.80 puts and bought 250 December $4.60 puts, they said. Lind Waldock also was a fairly active buyer of wheat futures, which may have been a hedge against the put demand, they said.
Wheat options volume was estimated at 6,000, up from 4,334 Thursday.
